The city walls can be reached via stairs from several points throughout the First Circle of Minas Tirith.\n\nStroll with Bergil up upon the outer walls of Minas Tirith. If you should get separated, the whistle Bergil gave you will call him back.
Ranks of soldiers can be found near the City Gates.\n\nTake Bergil to see more ranks of soldiers.

'There they are! If only the sun were shining, how fine their gleaming arms and armour would be.\n\n'Look, there are others, over there. Let us get a look at those ones, too!'
While touring the city walls with Bergil, you have crossed paths with Oryat, the soldier who berated Bergil earlier. You should intervene before he lays his hands on the boy.

A thought seems to suddenly strike Bergil.

'Say, when did you get here, [placeholder]? Were you upon the Pelennor when Lord Faramir came back to us? How I should like to have seen that! I went to the gates with Pippin - that's the prince of the halflings I spoke of - when all the men arrived from Belfalas and Lossarnach and elsewhere. That was a sight to see. But they only rode in on their horses. That is fine, but it is nothing to a fight!

'How would you like to go up upon the walls and see what we can? I hear the Enemy is within the Rammas Echor now and would like dreadfully to see how that is. I can hardly imagine it!'
Rossaran the Swan-knight stands near the rude soldiers, inside the main gates of Minas Tirith.\n\nA swan-knight took note of the soldiers who were rude to Bergil, and seems to want to speak with you.

You intervened to keep Oryat from striking Bergil, and Oryat challenged you to what is surely an ill-advised duel.\n\nSee where Bergil wishes to go now. If you should get separated, the whistle Bergil gave you will call him back.

'What fun we've had, strolling about, [placeholder]! I will not let that last grim turn spoil my enjoyment of the day, and I hope you won't either.\n\n'Still, it will be hard not going to any Upper Circles. I owe it to the others to find some way out of this - or around it - if I can.'

'Got a spine then after all, have we? I reckoned there was a chance you might - so I made sure I had some friends at hand.\n\n'Ha ha! Why should I chance a wound for the sorry likes of you!'

Himnir smiles indulgently at Bergil.

'Sweets not just for you, but also for the other children? Well, that is a bold thing to ask! Others would pay good coin for such a parcel of my goods. Ah, but who am I fooling? Like as not, I would have given it to you freely.

'Today, however, I have an errand you may run to earn your treat. This whisk I use to whip up cream for my pastries has come apart, and it is my favourite whisk!

'I ask you to bring it to Amonel, a tinker in the Wrights' Market, and beg her to set it right. In return, I'll have a bounty of sweets sent over for the whole lot of you.'
Fed a horse ([placeholder]/[placeholder])

'You showed bravery just now, both of you. Sometimes we rush into a fight that might be averted. Other times we do what must be done, even though the consequences of our acts bring us no good fortune. You must ask yourself which you have chosen. But regardless of what lesson you draw, you will live with the result.\n\n'You have won yourself freedom in the First Circle, but neither you nor any of the other children should venture up here anymore. Oryat will surely do you harm. I read that plainly in his eyes.'
Looked out from over the City Gates

'Well, this is an odd pairing!'

The tinker eyes you and Bergil.

'So, old Himnir's favourite whisk finally failed him. Go lightly with it, I told him! Ah, well. Let me have a look and see what I can do.

'You come back in a while and with any luck, I'll have it fixed.'

'Not venture into the Second Circle? I suppose we dare not, lest Oryat find us. Oh, [placeholder]! What have we done? Somehow I felt for sure that if only you bested Oryat, he would never trouble us anymore.

'We had better not stay. I shall go back to the Old Guest-house now. I must think and talk with the other children.

'Will you meet me there?'
'You'll crawl off with your tail between your legs. We'll see to that!'
talk to the foodmonger
hear the bully out
'Let us go, [placeholder]. Perhaps Amonel has finished mending that whisk.'

The Foodmongers' Market lies in the northern stretch of the First Circle.\n\nHelp Bergil find the foodmonger Himnir and ask for a treat for all the children. If you should get separated from Bergil, the whistle he gave you will call him back.
'A cautious step and keen judgement. Remember that!'

The Knight gives the slightest of nods to you, and then addresses Bergil.

'It pains me that even in this dark hour, we cannot count on each other for common kindness. Yet it is ever so.

'Young man, know that had he raised his arm to you, I would have intervened. I saw clearly that this [placeholder], your companion, was one breath from doing the same.

'But someone elder and stronger than you cannot be always by your side. I therefore council you to look before you step, and to learn to judge the character of men before they are within striking range. Look into their eyes. You will learn to know. See that one there, who so discourteously spoke to you? An unhappy storm is writ upon his face.

'You may grow to be strong and maybe even take the trappings of a knight in your time. But a cautious step and keen judgement will guard you from blows that no armour ever can.'

The Wrights' Market lies in the southern stretch of the First Circle.\n\nBring the broken whisk to the tinker Amonel in the Wrights' Market, as Himnir asked. If you should get separated from Bergil, the whistle he gave you will call him back.
'They brought out new apple crates just this morning. Let us feed the horses!'
'Isn't it funny how their lips brush against your hand?'

'A cautious step and what was it, clear judgement? I must commit those words, for they seem good ones to live by.

'Fa! I am shaking a bit from that mean fellow, though I do not like to admit it. Let us look elsewhere, on something more pleasant.

'See the horses over there? Shall we feed them some apples?'

Amonel greets you and Bergil with a low sigh.

'The whisk is not mended. Nor shall it be, for it is beyond repair. Himnir should not go so hard on so delicate a tool and I have told him so...

'Nor will I send you to bear this ill tiding for me. Some things must be faced bravely. A knight cannot send someone in his stead to face the foe, nor can he shirk his duty and let innocents come to harm.

'Go now. Somehow I think Himnir will send some sweets to your friends all the same.'

'No doubt you saw, when we met, that I am not the only youth in Minas Tirith. Mind you, most left with the wains some days past. But a dozen of us remained for this reason and that.\n\n'It is for them, as well as I myself, I wish to ask Himnir for some treats.'
Feed the horses ([placeholder]/[placeholder])
'The Wrights' Market! I wouldn't mind poking my nose in there, anyway. This Amonel, she must be awfully clever with her hands. Tinkers are, you know!'
'Bring that broken whisk to Amonel, around or about the Wrights' Market, and I'll send treats for all your friends.'
'Run along. This will take a moment... or two. I haven't decided yet how the whisk could be fixed.'
thank youl. now about this bully - you've got to stand up for yourself!
'A tour of the city walls is just the thing. I wish to see everything I can up there!'

Talk to Bergil
'You, boy. You don't belong here. Get out of my sight!'
'Skulking urchins, eh Hanar? Always underfoot!'

'Greetings! Not four days past I met the prince of the halflings, and now you! Does a halfling army follow, to come to Gondor's aid?'

When you tell him there is not, he seems crestfallen. A moment later, his face lights up again.

'But you are full-grown, like he, are you not? And a friend to the City? Then you should walk with me! I'll show you things to see. And we can go places I would be shooed away from, were I alone!

'Here, take this whistle. If we somehow get separated, you sound it and I'll come running.'
Bergil has invited you on a stroll around the First Circle of Minas Tirith.
'Cross my sight again and you'll earn a bruise to show for it!'

'Greetings! I am friend to the prince of halflings - and now I've met a dwarf! Are you a prince, by any chance?'

When you tell him that you are not, he seems crestfallen. A moment later, his face lights up again.

'All the same, you are a stranger in the city. Will you walk with me? I'll show you things to see. And we can go places I would be shooed away from, were I alone!

'Here, take this whistle. If we somehow get separated, you sound it and I'll come running.'
'Boys that can't heed their elders need to be taught a lesson.'

'She speaks nearly as well as the swan-knight, [placeholder]. Some things must be faced bravely...

'Do you know what I think? I think that you must face that swaggering soldier, Oryat! Surely you are a match for him. Surely you can cow him and make him relent.

'Please, [placeholder]. He will not leave us children alone until someone stops him. Oh, and how I would love to see you stand him on his head!'

'Greetings! I am friend to the prince of the halflings. Have you ever seen a halfling? I'll wager you haven't.'

When you tell him that you in fact have, he seems crestfallen. A moment later, his face lights up again.

'All the same, you are a stranger in the city. Will you walk with me? I'll show you things to see. And we can go places I would be shooed away from, were I alone!

'Here, take this whistle. If we somehow get separated, you sound it and I'll come running.'
'There are others over there!'

'And just what are you then, the champion of orphans and wretches? What gives you the right to stand between me, a soldier of Gondor, and that impudent, sniveling, little...'

He makes as if to go past you, then sees the dangerous look in your eye.

'Oho, is that how it is? You'd strike at me, would you, just to spare this urchin a bit of a thrashing? Just you try it. I'm a soldier trained and hardened, and I'll strike back. I'll strike whatever cheeky boy or foreigner I choose, to let them know their place.

'Now skulk away - or if you've any spine, meet me up in the Second Circle later, between the Feasting Hall and the tavern, and we'll see who strikes who, when it comes to it.'
'Those soldiers, there. Let us get closer to them.'
Oryat stands back, glowering at you
